H0.text: Swimming speed is increased by an individual fish when a group of the same species swim together.

H1.text: Body temperature is increased by a group of the same species of fish swimming together.

H2.text: Chance of survival is increased when a group of the same species of fish swim together.

H3.text: Visibility to predators is increased for an individual when a group of the same species of fish swim together.

A4.text: Fish derive many benefits from shoaling behaviour including defence against predators (through better predator detection and by diluting the chance of individual capture), enhanced foraging success, and higher success in finding a mate.

A5.text: The oddity effect posits that any shoal member that stands out in appearance will be preferentially targeted by predators, thus homogenising shoals.
